data.meta_description: A time-coded and annotated breakdown of Peter Jackson's "The Beatles: Get Back" documentary.
data.text:
The Beatles: Get Back

Time-Coded and Annotated

.

Some of the characters beyond the Fab Five:

(And yes, itâ€™s five â€” because in this doc The Beatles become a quintet. ğŸ˜‰)

Peter Jackson â€” the cinematic master behind this entire production

Jabez Olssen â€” Peter Jacksonâ€™s super-skilled right-hand-man editor â€“ never seen on screen, but is a part of every second of footage

George Martin â€” The Beatlesâ€™ Music Producer, one of a handful cited as being â€œthe fifth Beatle,â€ dapper, suave, smart and cool

Michael Lindsay-Hogg â€” original 1969 Director â€“ directed The Rolling Stones Rock n Roll Circus the month before, and The Beatlesâ€™ Hey Jude and Revolution videos at Twickenham four months earlier â€“ hereinafter referred to as MLH

Tony Richmond â€” original 1969 Director of Photography â€“ also the D.P. on The Rolling Stones Rock n Roll Circus the month before â€“ with the mustache, looks like Freddie Prinze

Glyn Johns â€” Recording Engineer & Co-Producer â€“ looks like Nicky Hopkins â€“ dresses like Austin Powers (as Peter Jackson joked). The New York Times even did a funnyâ€“cool piece about it.

Alan Parsons â€” credited as Tape Operator (was only at Savile Row, not Twickenham). Seven years after the events of this movie he would go on to write & produce one of the great albums of all time, Tales of Mystery and Imagination (Edgar Allen Poe) which you can hear in its entirety here.

Denis Oâ€™Dell â€” Apple Films Producer â€“ associate producer of A Hard Dayâ€™s Night, producer of Magical Mystery Tour, and was producing The Magic Christian with Peter Sellers and Ringo as Get Back gets started â€” looks like Milos Forman

Mal Evans â€” beloved Road Manager & Assistant to The Beatles â€“ been with them since the Cavern days

Kevin Harrington â€” Beatles Roadie â€“ the ginger-haired kid â€“ looks like Ed Sheeran

Neil Aspinall â€” Producer / Apple Corps Managing Director â€“ childhood friend of Paul & George, started out as the bandâ€™s van driver back in the Pete Best days

Peter Brown â€” the bandâ€™s quasi manager after Brian Epstein died â€“ started as a salesman at Epsteinâ€™s NEMS music store in Liverpool

Derek Taylor â€” The Beatlesâ€™ Publicist â€“ originally a journalist, Epstein hired him to work for the band full-time in early 1964

Ethan Russell â€” 23-year-old still photographer in the sessions â€“ had shot the Stonesâ€™ Rock n Roll Circus the month before â€“ his portraits of the band members are on the Let It Be album cover â€“ cool short 2020 interview with him here.

Chris Oâ€™Dell â€” American-born Apple employee, roof concert guest, rock n roll adventurer, author of a great memoir, and a YouTube storyteller. (No relation to Denis)

Robert Fraser â€” nicknamed â€œGroovy Bobâ€ by Terry Southern, he was a leading â€œSwinging Londonâ€ art dealer and all â€™round bon vivant who put on Johnâ€™s first Yoko-inspired avant garde art show â€œYou Are Hereâ€ at his gallery in July of â€™68.

Les Parrott â€” Camera Operator

Peter Sutton â€” Sound Recordist ğŸ™‚

Paul Bond â€” Clapper Boy and Additional Camera

Dave Harries â€” Apple Sound Engineer

Sally Burgess â€” from the Apple Press Office, short red-ish haired woman with the big glasses at Savile Row

Debbie Wellum â€” Apple Receptionist and unsung hero for delaying the cops in the lobby

Jimmy Clark â€” Dapper Doorman

Bob Smeaton â€” thanked in credits â€” Anthology & Festival Express director

=========================

The must-see nearly 4-hour Peter Jackson interview:

=========================

The songs that seem to be directly (or subconsciously) about where the band is at and where theyâ€™re heading â€”

â€“ All Things Must Pass (January 3rd)

â€“ Two Of Us (On Our Way Home) (January 6th)

â€“ Get Back (January 7th)

â€“ Carry That Weight (a long time) (January 9th)

â€“ Let It Be (January 9th)

â€“ Bye Bye Love (Everly Brothers song) (January 25th)

==========================

The credits run 6Â½ minutes at the end of each episode. In episode 3, they run concurrent with footage. But in episodes 1 & 2 they run with a black screen â€” so you can knock 13 minutes off the total run time of 468 minutes = 455 minutes = a 7Â½ hour documentary.

==========================

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED TO TURN ON THE CLOSED CAPTIONING â€” VIA LITTLE BOX IN EXTREME UPPER RIGHT OF DISNEY SCREEN.

EPISODE ONE â€” Days 1 thru 7 â€” January 2nd thru 10th, 1969

2 hours & 30 mins (plus 6:50 minutes of credits)

Writing / Rehearsals at Twickenham

The opening title cards that appear before each episode:

â€œThe â€˜Get Backâ€™ project in January 1969 produced over 60 hours of film footage and more than 150 hours of audio recordings.â€

â€œNumerous editorial choices had to be made during the production of these films.â€

â€œScenes that contain audio-only material have been supplemented with representative pictures.â€

â€œAt all times, the film-makers have attempted to present an accurate portrait of the events depicted and the people involved.â€

0:40 â€“ 11:00 â€” starts with an 11-minute recap of their career.

Opens with audio of The Quarrymen singing the early McCartney/Harrison original In Spite of All The Danger â€” set to historical footage of Liverpool in the late 1950s.

Other than the minor date / age errors, this is a good basic quick Beatles history narrative set-up to how we got to the sessions and film weâ€™re about to see.

Peter Jackson is a *great* cinematic storyteller.

11:00 â€” DAY ONE â€” Thursday, January 2nd, 1969

Of note â€” the band was last in the recording studio October 17th, 1968 â€” only 2Â½ months earlier â€” finishing recording The White Album.

Great use of the calendar to show the days â€” a smart / easy-to-follow story structure.

Love that Mal Evans is the first person we meet as the January journey begins.

11:30 â€” On The Road To Marrakesh/Child of Nature (later to be Jealous Guy) â€” Johnâ€™s singing voice begins the story, just as it did the band.

Itâ€™s so cool to see the Twickenham soundstage completely empty, then begin to get filled in.

Boy â€” is the editing ever good right outta the gate!! Gawd â€” this is GREAT filmmaking!

And the pictures are so sharp! Wow.

12:05 â€” George correctly asks, â€œWhereâ€™s the console? The mixer and the 8-tracks and all them.â€ ğŸ™‚

12:15 â€” John leading George & Ringo through a part of Everybodyâ€™s Got Soul â€“ a Lennon song that never got finished.

Peter Jacksonâ€™s doing a *great* job with the title cards explaining whatâ€™s happening and why. The band must write, perform and record 14 new songs in the next two weeks. (!)

12:35 â€” Donâ€™t Let Me Down â€” new John song â€” first early run-thru.

13:15 â€” George correctly points out â€œI donâ€™t think this is a very acoustically good place.â€

13:35 â€” Co-producers of the album Glyn Johns & George Martin first appear.

13:55 â€” MLH asks the band to turn down their amps because itâ€™s drowning out their conversations, and George asks, â€œAre you recording our conversations?â€ ğŸ˜„

14:20 â€” Iâ€™ve Got A Feeling â€” Paul teaching it to the band.

John & Paul sitting side by side and having fun.

Great camerawork and editing!

16:20 â€” the first meeting off to the side. Paul is the only bandmember in it! George Martin mentions how Twickenham is not good acoustically. He wants to do something with a PA, like doing a live performance, because it will â€œtriggerâ€ something. Film Producer Denis Oâ€™Dell is in on the conversation, explaining how heâ€™s leased Twickenham until the end of May to film The Magic Christian (with Peter Sellers & Ringo Starr). MLH wants a â€œspectacularâ€ venue for the performance climax.

17:25 â€” Johnny B. Goode bit

17:35 â€” Quinn the Eskimo bit

17:44 â€” I Shall Be Released bit

18:00 â€” Yoko in the shiny black (satin?) body suit.

18:30 â€” Donâ€™t Let Me Down â€” Paul helping John write it â€” theyâ€™re obviously a team â€¦ and writing together.

19:40 â€” Paul, Glyn, MLH discussing where to play a concert. MLH pushing for the amphitheater in Libya â€” but Ringo â€œput his foot downâ€ that heâ€™s not traveling.

Paul to MLH: â€œI think youâ€™ll find weâ€™re not going abroad.â€ ğŸ˜†

21:25 â€” Two of Us (On Our Way Home) â€” Paul teaching it to the band, working out lyrics.

23:30 â€” DAY TWO â€” Friday, January 3rd

23:35 â€” Paul on grand piano, Ringo tap dancing.

23:40 â€” Great shot of the colored lights being turned on, creating the beautiful wash on the floor-to-ceiling scrim behind the band.

23:47 â€” George reading the latest Beatle fanzine â€” including about Paul visiting official Beatles biographer Hunter Davies in Portugal.

24:30 â€” George talking about all the songs heâ€™s written â€“ â€œand theyâ€™re all slowish.â€

24:45 â€” Taking a Trip to Carolina â€” by Ringo! Then he sings it while playing the grand piano.

25:50 â€” Paul & George talking about getting 8-track recording equipment and how EMI should be taking care of it.

26:30 â€” Paul says there are about 100 songs John & he wrote together in the early days that they never recorded.

26:40 â€” Just Fun (Lennon/McCartney)

26:55 â€” Because I Know You Love Me So (Lennon/McCartney)

27:40 â€” Thinking of Linking (Lennon/McCartney)

27:55 â€” Wonâ€™t You Please Say Goodbye (Lennon/McCartney)

28:15 â€” One After 909 (Lennon/McCartney) â€“ old song that they loved â€“ laughing and having a great time

Cool early B&W photos and young John & Paul playing together.

30:00 â€” goofing on Ob-La-Di Ob-La-Da. (Lennon/McCartney)

30:20 â€” Midnight Special (traditional, Leadbelly)

30:35 â€” What Do You Want To Make Those Eyes At Me For? (written by Howard Johnson, James V. Monaco, and Joseph McCarthy in 1916, a hit for Emile Ford & the Checkmates in 1959)

30:50 â€” The Harry Lime Theme aka The Third Man Theme (instrumental, by Anton Karas, 1949 film score)

31:45 â€” George gets shocked by microphone.

32:30 â€” working on Iâ€™ve Got A Feeling â€“ writing the lyrics / coming up with arrangement.

34:00 â€” Mal keeping track of the lyrics with pen and paper. ğŸ’–

34:45 â€” They ask Mal to time Donâ€™t Let Me Down cuz John thinks â€œitâ€™s only about â€˜alf a minute longâ€ ğŸ™‚ â€” turns out to be 3 minutes 40 seconds! ğŸ˜

34:55 â€” Donâ€™t Let Me Down â€“ partial

35:35 â€” Gimme Some Truth !! â€” jointly composed by John & Paul; would later appear on Imagine as a John song.

37:05 â€” Lowrey organ carried in.

37:30 â€” All Things Must Pass â€” first time playing for band â€“ John on Lowrey organ.

Like Paulâ€™s Get Back â€” another song that seems subconsciously (or consciously) about where the band is at and going.

They are all jointly composing/arranging the song.

Really shows yet again their collaborative process.

40:00 â€” Somebody asks if they want pale ales.

Paul gets a pale ale.

George â€” white wine.

John â€” â€œIâ€™ll have a beer.â€

Ringo nothing.

40:00 â€” George advocates for their live recording approach as opposed to the overdubs of The White Album etc.

He also talks about maybe including â€œsome oldies but goldiesâ€ in the TV show so the audience can recognize something â€“ but then says it would be okay if the show aired a week after the album was released. So funny how they just take as a fact of life that their fans would know the songs a week after their album was released. ğŸ˜®

Paul looks high. ğŸ˜

41:25 â€” George recommends bringing back Every Little Thing (Lennon/McCartney) from their 1964 Beatles For Sale album.

41:55 â€” George talking favorably about Claptonâ€™s leads and improvising, and how George isnâ€™t as good at that.

42:25 â€” Paul: â€œItâ€™s jazz, man.â€

42:45 â€” George mentions Ray Charles and Billy Preston! â€œThe best jazz band I saw was Ray Charlesâ€™ band. That jazz really moves me in a fantastic way. Billy Preston is too much! Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll dig it when you see it. Billy plays piano with the band. Then he does his own spot where he sings and dances and plays organ solo. Then Ray Charles comes on. Heâ€™s better than Ray Charles, really, because heâ€™s, like, too much! Because he plays organ so great. Ray Charles doesnâ€™t bother with the organ now. Heâ€™s just, â€˜Iâ€™ll leave it to the young guy.'â€

The show heâ€™s referring to having seen was the Saturday Sept. 21st 1968 Ray Charles show at the Royal Festival Hall in London, three months prior, which he says in the Anthology book (p. 318) that he attended with Eric Clapton. It has mistakenly entered Beatles lore that George saw Ray (and Billy) during the week he left the band later this month (and then invited Billy to the studio), but thatâ€™s not accurate. He saw them in Sept. â€™68. And heâ€™s talking about having seen them on January 3rd, before he took his break from the band a week later.

43:22 â€” Iâ€™m So Tired â€” Paul has red eyes like he just stepped out for a spliff. ğŸ¤ª

Great eye-rubbing â€œtiredâ€ footage. ğŸ‘ This is the end of their second day back working together after 2Â½ months.

Of most interesting note: also on this day but not included in the doc was a conversation where George tells Paul about seeing Beat poet Michael McClureâ€™s play The Beard, prompting me to explore that beatific Beatâ€“Beatles confluence and uncover a ton of cool new stuff about that connection that you can read here. ğŸ˜‰

44:30 â€” DAY 3 â€” Monday, January 6th

44:30 â€” Glyn & Paul talking about getting Georgeâ€™s and EMIâ€™s recording equipment into Twickenham. (MLH & Tony Richmond also present.)

Glyn stressing that this filmed show be approached as a live performance.

45:00 â€” Ringo arrives hungover hazy. â€œI wonâ€™t lie. Iâ€™m not too good.â€ ğŸ˜

45:10 â€” MLH pestering that they should be thinking about the show. Paul responds, â€œBut we are thinking about the show.â€ ğŸ˜ And John goes, â€œWe never stop thinking about it.â€ ğŸ˜

The band are just waking up, just coming to, and again MLH goes on about it â€” â€œWouldnâ€™t it be nice if we did this show with a big audience?â€

George responds: â€œI think we should forget the whole idea of the show.â€ ğŸ˜†

Paul goes: â€œYeah, okay, Iâ€™ll go along with that. Weâ€™re back to square one.â€

MLH is SO painfully out of synch with the band (and Glyn).

45:35 â€” Georgeâ€™s 8-track arrives.

45:55 â€” Great edit â€” George H asks, â€œIs [Magic] Alex going to plug all that up?â€ And Peter Jackson cuts to George Martin, who gives a classy knowing â€œYeah, rightâ€ smirk. ğŸ˜„ Then George M goes on to say that Alex rang him up yesterday and said the band didnâ€™t need an 8-track because Alex was going to build one. (!)

I only know George Martin from various interviews over the decades, but I gotta imagine the lads could read instantly how seriously George Martin took Magic Alex. ğŸ™‚

46:00 â€” Magic Alex footage â€” he first met John â€” who made the mistake of trusting/believing in him â€” like he would soon do with Allen Klein and Phil Spector. ğŸ˜¥

46:50 â€” You Wear Your Women Out (writing credit to all four)

47:05 â€” My Imagination â€” also credited as group-composed â€“ short high-energy jam â€“ nice surreal camerawork / editing.

47:25â€“56:00 â€” group writing Donâ€™t Let Me Down

47:25 â€” Paul, John & George working on the lyrics / arrangement.

48:25 â€” They start talking about needing a piano player. John: â€œWe need a guy that plays piano all the time.â€ Paul: â€œSomebody like Nicky Hopkins.â€

49:00 â€” John mentions â€œwatching that pop show on BBC2. The Move were on.â€ (Roy Woodâ€™s band) He mentions how their voices were different and â€œthey never joined into a group.â€

Paul is very much leading the working out of the arrangement.

50:56 â€” Hare Krishna guys in Twickenham.

52:35 â€” Love to see the boys using pens on paper writing the lyrics. ğŸ¥°

Itâ€™s very much the three of them â€” Paul, John & George â€” who are more or less equally batting around ideas.

53:25 â€” producer Glyn Johns sits among them also throwing in ideas.

This is something about The Beatles â€” that from the very beginning they were open to collaborating â€” from following Brian Epsteinâ€™s advice, to embracing George Martin, to the carte blanche they gave Richard Lester, and all down the line through photographers and tailors and art designers â€” they were very open to incorporating other artistsâ€™ input. ğŸ˜‰

54:24 â€” Paul counts in Johnâ€™s song â€” like John later counts in Paulâ€™s.

55:05 â€” George says that what theyâ€™ve come up with is corny. â€œI think itâ€™s awful . . . If you had a tape recorder now and recorded that and played it back youâ€™d throw that out straightaway.â€ ğŸ˜†

Even though theyâ€™re not solidifying the magic at the moment â€” itâ€™s clear they are three equals working together. (With, of course, Ringo laying down exactly the right backing for what the three frontmen come up with.)

56:15â€“1:02:14 â€” group writing Two Of Us

Again, itâ€™s the three of them bouncing off each other. Paul is definitely in a bit of a quasi-leadership role.

57:30 â€” The beginning of the â€œIâ€™ll play whatever pleases youâ€ scene â€”

Seeing the full lead-in and lead-out from that, unlike in MLHâ€™s Let It Be â€” you now see it in context.

57:48 â€” Paul gets up and takes his guitar off. â€œI canâ€™t do this on camera.â€

58:00 â€” Paul: â€œIâ€™m scared of me being the boss. And I have been for, like, a couple of years.â€ Paul to George: â€œI always feel as though Iâ€™m trying to put you down and stop you playing. But Iâ€™m not. Iâ€™m trying to stop us all playing until we know what weâ€™re playing.â€

58:10 â€” George: â€œBut youâ€™ve got to play in order to find which fits and which doesnâ€™t. Thatâ€™s all we can do.â€

58:40 â€” Paul: â€œBut doesnâ€™t everyone agree that itâ€™s confused at the moment. So, all Iâ€™m trying to say is weâ€™ve only got 12 more days, so weâ€™ve really got to do this methodically.â€

George: â€œIâ€™ll wait until you get all your bits and then work my part out if you like. Itâ€™s a matter of working it out with you while youâ€™re working your bit out. You know, have you got your bass bit?â€

Paul gets defensive or is frustrated. â€œIâ€™m not trying to get to you. I really am trying to just say, â€˜Look lads, the band, shall we try it like this, you know?â€™ Itâ€™s funny though how it only occurs when the â€” itâ€™s like, â€˜Shall we play guitar all through Hey Jude?â€™ Well, I donâ€™t think we should.â€

George: â€œYeah, okay, well, I donâ€™t mind. Iâ€™ll play, you know, whatever you want me to play. Or I wonâ€™t play at all if you donâ€™t want me to play. Now, whatever it is that will please you, Iâ€™ll do it. (pause all around) But I donâ€™t think you really know what that one is.â€

And thatâ€™s the whole thing . . . that has been twisted out of context and blown out of proportion for all these decades.

George is being totally cool and is not annoyed. Theyâ€™re just working it out.

Itâ€™s almost exactly like the conversation they were having minutes earlier about Donâ€™t Let Me Down.

This is a TOTALLY normal conversation between guys in a band sitting around jamming ideas on a song.

Even right after this mistaken-for-tense moment, theyâ€™re all just carrying on a normal conversation between bandmates.

Even Two Of Us (On Our Way Home) is like a song written to and about the band. (I know it was inspired by he & Linda â€” but art is filled with creators tapping one vein that echoes another. ğŸ˜‰)

All Things Must Pass . . . On Our Way Home . . . Get Back . . . all songs addressing where they are as a band and where theyâ€™d like to be heading â€” subconsciously or consciously. Wild.

1:02:30 â€” DAY 4 â€” Tuesday, January 7th

1:02:35 â€” Paul, joking: â€œLennonâ€™s late again. Thinking of getting rid of him.â€ ğŸ˜

1:02:48 â€” George, joking: â€œYouâ€™re playing that bass again,â€ referring to Paul strapping on his classic Hofner.

1:02:55 â€” Paul & George asking soundman Peter for better mics.

* * 1:03:10â€“1:06:40 â€” Paul starts writing Get Back * * â€” in a way the song is a hymnal entreaty to the band â€œto get back to where they once belonged.â€

Ringo listening intently.

George starts playing along â€” Ringo starts clapping a beat, then singing harmony!

1:06:15 â€” Ringo moves to the drums.

1:06:40 â€” suddenly Lennonâ€™s there on guitar.

1:06:55 â€” four bandmates & MLH & Glyn Johns talking about the show / concert.

MLH says Denis Oâ€™Dell suggested doing it there at Twickenham, but MLH wants to do it somewhere better. â€œBecause you are The Beatles.â€ . . .

Paul: â€œThe only thing about that is, we donâ€™t want to go away.â€

Then MLH goes on about it AGAIN! â€œThink of the lights on the water. Torch-lit. 2,000 Arabs. Visually itâ€™s fantastic.â€ ğŸ™‚

Paul says again: â€œBut weâ€™re not going away.â€

Then MLH goes at it AGAIN: â€œI will every day say Tripoli.â€

Then Paul says: â€œWe should do the show in a place where weâ€™re not allowed to do it. You know, like, we should trespass, go in, set up, and then get moved, and that should be the show.â€

1:07:46 â€” Then he jokes about playing in the main gallery at the Houses of Parliament â€œand getting forcibly ejected, still trying to play numbers, and the police lifting you,â€ then mimics getting dragged away singing She Came In Through The Bathroom Window. ğŸ¤£

Then MLH becomes a full-on Monty Python character saying, â€œWhat about a hospital? But I donâ€™t mean for really sick kids. I mean for kids with broken legs. . . . Or maybe an orphanâ€™s home. What about an orphanage? How does that grab you guys?â€ ğŸ˜³

Some say John seems detached. Maybe heâ€™s high, but I see him as simply listening and thinking.

1:09:23 â€” John: â€œIâ€™ve decided the whole point of it is communication. And to be on TV is communication. Weâ€™ve got a chance to smile at people, like All You Need Is Love. So thatâ€™s my incentive for doing it.â€

John: â€œThe worst that we have is a documentary of us making an LP.â€

The break-up conversation:

Paul: â€œBut we havenâ€™t played together, you see. Thatâ€™s the fucking thing. But when we do come together to play together, we all just sort of talk about the fucking past! Weâ€™re like old age pensioners. â€˜Remember the days when we used to rock?â€™ ğŸ˜… But weâ€™re here now, and we can do it, you know? But all I want to see is enthusiasm. See, the thing is also â€“ I get to a bit where I just sort of push all my ideas.â€

George: â€œA lot will come out of it if we could get the enthusiasm.â€

Paul: â€œI mean, why are you here? Iâ€™m here because I wanna do a show. But I really donâ€™t feel an awful lot of support.â€

George: â€œWe keep coming up against that one, and I keep saying, â€˜Yeah well, Iâ€™d like to do this, this and that.â€™ And we end up doing something again that nobody really wants to do.â€

* 1:10:35 â€” Paul: â€œIf this one turns into that, it should definitely be the last for all of us.â€ (!) â€œBecause there just isnâ€™t any point. Itâ€™s stupid. Itâ€™s just stupid. The people who are being stupid are the four of us.â€

* 1:11:00 â€” George: â€œWe need to be creative, instead of being in the doldrums, which it always is. The Beatles have been in the doldrums for at least a year. Ever since Mr. Epstein passed away, itâ€™s never been the same.â€

[As confirmed in this doc, and also from doing a deep dive into other sources, it was really the unfortunate death of â€œMr. Epsteinâ€ that started an inevitable domino tumble towards dissolution.]

Paul: â€œWeâ€™ve been very negative since Mr. Epstein passed away. And thatâ€™s why all of us, in turn, have been sick of the group. Itâ€™s discipline we lack. Weâ€™ve never had discipline. We had a sort of slight, symbolic discipline. Like Mr. Epstein. You know, and he sort of said, â€˜Get suits on,â€™ and we did. We were always fighting that discipline a bit. (everybody laughs) There really is no one now to say, â€˜Do it,â€™ whereas there always used to be. Daddyâ€™s gone away now, and weâ€™re on our own at the holiday camp. And I think we either go home or we do it. I think weâ€™ve got a bit shy of certain things. I think Iâ€™ve gotten a bit shy of certain things. Cuz you know how often, like, on albums we sometimes blow one of your songs [to John] cuz we come in in the wrong mood. And you say, â€˜This is how it goes. Iâ€™ll be back.â€™ And weâ€™re all just, â€˜Oh, well you â€¦ (scat sings)â€™ So itâ€™s like, if weâ€™re doing the show, then weâ€™re gonna have to work hard. And that means by the time a week from now comes all these songs weâ€™ve got, we gotta know perfectly.â€

George: â€œI donâ€™t wanna do any of my songs on the show (!) because theyâ€™ll just turn out shitty.â€

Paul: â€œNo, but â€” thinking itâ€™s not gonna come out great wonâ€™t help. If we cancel the show now, weâ€™ll be throwing it away.â€

MLH: â€œBut equally, at the moment we havenâ€™t got a show, and so none of us really want to do it.â€

* 1:12:35 Paul: â€œIâ€™ll do it. Iâ€™m not interested in spending my fucking days farting around here while everyone makes up their minds whether they want to do it or not. Itâ€™s like Mal said last night, â€˜If youâ€™re gonna do the show here, youâ€™ve gotta decide today.â€™ And as far as I can see, thereâ€™s only two ways â€” weâ€™re gonna do it, or weâ€™re not gonna do it. And I want a decision!â€

* 1:12:57 â€” George: â€œMaybe we should have a divorce.â€

Paul: â€œI said that at the last meeting. But itâ€™s getting nearer, you know.â€

John: â€œWhoâ€™d have the children?â€ ğŸ¤£ the guy who adds levity to the heavy.

Paul: â€œDick James.â€ ğŸ˜¥ (the guy whoâ€™s ripping them off for their royalties)

MLH: â€œWe all need you. And if you canâ€™t get it together, thatâ€™s really very sad. I think what we should do now is let you play a little.â€

All agree.

1:13:50â€“1:17:30 â€” Maxwellâ€™s Silver Hammer â€” Paul on grand piano, very upbeat, teaching the song to and working it up with band.

George on the Fender Bass VI.

Whistling â€“ and tongue clucking.

Theyâ€™re all very chipper and goofing shortly after their heavy conversation about the band breaking up.

1:15:00 â€” band goes to lunch (in the Twickenham cafeteria)

Paul says as heâ€™s walking out: â€œMal â€“ we should get a hammer. . . . And an anvil.â€ ğŸ˜‚

Mal looks around, like â€œHuh? . . . Me? . . . . . . An anvil? . . .â€ ğŸ˜„

1:15:20 â€” Mal on the anvil (!) HUGE smile on his face ğŸ˜

Re: George leaving the band:

Peter Jackson said in that must-see 4-hour discussion about the film (in the YouTube link at the top of this page) that at the time George left the band he was also having a domestic crisis at home, which Jackson didnâ€™t include in the doc, in part because there was probably no audio or video of it, and also he didnâ€™t want to get into those kinds of personal side stories. But Pattie Boyd writes about it in her memoir Wonderful Tonight that at this exact time in early January â€™69, George was having an affair with a 20-year-old French girl (Charlotte Martin), and Pattie actually left him over it. Plus his mother was seriously ill up in Liverpool (necessitating Georgeâ€™s trip there mentioned in episode two), so there were serious external pressures in his life besides whatever was going on with the band.

Some observations after 2 episodes / 5Â½ hours, and just before the climactic episode drops at 3AM (Eastern) . . .

Iâ€™m SO glad â€” as Peter Jackson said, when they were given the 6-hour window by Disney, Peter & his editor very quickly decided, and I quote, â€œLetâ€™s just make the movie we want,â€ he said, rubbing his hands together. ğŸ˜ And he said he included everything a Beatles fan would want to see, because (something like) â€œIf we donâ€™t put it in, itâ€™s just going to go back in a vault for another 50 years.â€

The fur coat John wears on the roof and is always referred to as Yokoâ€™s was in fact the coat John always wears and carries with him. And according to Deep Beatles aficionado Jan Fennick, the coat was actually his wife Cynthiaâ€™s motherâ€™s!

My 33-year-old neighbor told me how sheâ€™s been watching it with her daughter, who has become a huge Beatles fan. Iâ€™ve read similar comments online about how people are experiencing this intergenerationally. This is a beautiful thing. How many other rock bands / pop artists would evoke such a response?

John & Paul are really a creative partnership. I was as guilty as many who thought theyâ€™d pretty much gone their separate ways even by The White Album the year before. But you can see them here looking into each otherâ€™s eyes and working up these songs in tandem.

It was so great to see Paul so strongly defending John bringing Yoko to the rehearsals. I had bought into the easy story that she had caused a fissure â€” but itâ€™s clear none of his three bandmates are bothered by her at all.

Itâ€™s so nice to see John really on top of it and in control by the time they moved to the Savile Row studio. I love how itâ€™s John who asks Billy Preston to join the band, and that we get to see Billyâ€™s ear-to-ear beaming reaction and blurting out â€œAre youâ€™re kidding?!?!â€ ğŸ¥°

Peter Jackson has done a masterful job showing the real-life drama that was going on â€” the pressure of the pending live concert deadline, the near breakup of the band, the desperate need for a keyboard player â€” and then one just shows up! Whadda story!!

I love how the band becomes a quintet â€” for both the sound and the energy. John says at one point, â€œIâ€™d like a fifth Beatle.â€ To which Paul jokes, â€œItâ€™s bad enough with four.â€

And I love how Paul is the big-picture structuralist, noticing the connections between the songs and mapping out a sequence â€” how Get Back and Two of Us (on our way home) are connected â€” and Donâ€™t Let Me Down reflects Oh! Darling.

I know itâ€™s been 5Â½ hours and will soon be nearly 8 â€” but this is the most intimate portrait ever made of the most influential band ever formed.

They knew the end was coming. In Part One there was talk of a â€œdivorceâ€ and in Part Two theyâ€™re talking about going out with a bang.

Itâ€™s SO bizarre that guitar stands and music stands were not staples of major studios and bandsâ€™ gear in January 1969. This is the biggest money-making group in the history of the world . . . and a Les Paul falls over at Twickenham cuz thereâ€™s no guitar stand in the joint! Then when they get to Apple, thereâ€™s not a one, and theyâ€™re always picking them up lying on the ground! Ringo is seen opening the packaging of the cheapest kind of music stand that exists â€¦ and heâ€™s got a kidâ€“onâ€“Christmasâ€“morning smile on his face like this is some treasured gift! How the hell does EMI or Apple not have tons of great music stands?!?!

And now, the entire rooftop concert â€” which no layperson has ever seen, ever â€” is about to be streamed on this blessed Beatles day, minutes away.
